description:
Always my favorite spot for some fresh and quality Vietnamese sandwiches in the city!  

Used to come here pretty often after school (Lincoln High), and their food is only getting better over the years. Their menu has expended to include more food items and they have also upgraded their sandwich bread. Instead of using the traditional round shaped bread they now substitute it with a flat kind of bread. I personally like the new bread  more bc it's more crispy in texture! 

Pro: they are very quick! You will probably get your food in and out within 5mins.  You will definitely come back after your first bite lol 

Con: it's a small shop so it is better to order to go :)
author: Shuyi L.

description:
The bread was so crunchy T-T The sandwich had a key ingredient: LOVE. :D Yes, you do have to wait a little.

Wasn't even going to get anything, but when I saw my friend's sandwich getting crafted, my despondent stomach reached out and whispered, "this is what I need!! I don't care if you weren't feeling hungry and all you want is boba and sleep!" 

Got #1, combination pork. Paid $5-6 range. This can't beat the Banh Mi Che Cali (looking at you, SoCal friend) BOGO prices, but still.. this sandwich made me happy. 

SO, just try it.
author: Donna L.

description:
The best of 3 places I've tried between the Outer Sunset. Parkside and Lakeside. Ample filling in the warm 5-spice chicken one with jalapenos. The bun was soft in the middle with a crunchy crust. Pickles 
 seasoned well.
author: Debbie T.

description: The best Viet sandwich the best part is the sandwich roll it's so crunchy even after a day not soggy the meat was very tasty !!! Definitely this is the best sandwich place ever! Take note cash only
author: Concepcion C.

description: The chicken tasted like it was from a can. Had the skin on it and was really slimy. Couldn't eat it.
author: Gabba D.

description:
Meh. I came here because I wanted to grab something portable to take with me before my puppers & I go to the dog park.

The dude making the sandwiches is super slow, didn't even greet me when I walked in. The bread they serve their sandwich on is unique, it's not a round french roll like most places but rather a flat rectangular one. The meat to bread ratio is off, it's mostly bread. Pate was lacking too. 

The sandwich was pretty tasty & it did the job but I wouldn't be back because it was only mediocre and it takes way too long to make a sandwich here.
author: Kelly L.

description: The best ones to get here are combo sandwich, BBQ pork, and all types of spring rolls. CASH ONLY
author: Phuong P.

description:
Went to grab two combo pork sandwiches today after our 2YO fell asleep in the car ride home. It was 2pm and the place was empty.

It's slow service since only one guy is working but it was clear he was moving as fast as he can... then he burned the bread and asked me if it was still ok? Ummm no. He puts more buns into the oven. The clock starts all over again. Took awhile just for two sandwiches. Anyhow it was good and portions were on point.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Their sandwich are pretty good but for the past 3 Saturdays (3 weeks in a row) their opening hours are not accurate. Store says open at 9am but still not open by 9:30am for the past 3 visits. Don't waste your time. Advise you to only go in the afternoon.
author: La G.

description:
This cat wanted to like this place. He really did, and honestly the sandwiches I've had here in the past are pretty good, but recent experiences have pushed me to growl and leave the dreaded one star review. 

I hopped in here and the woman behind the counter gave me a very bad attitude like she didn't want me to be there. I wanted to ask a question about one of the items on the menu and immediately she cut me off and said "only sandwich now!"

The guy who works there is much nicer I will say, but the lady seems always angry and will often ignore customers waiting to order. 

The last two times in a row I was there, two different sandwiches, the pork sandwich and the ham sandwich, I ended up getting sick. Not sure what exactly it is that is doing it, but both times I ended up super sick feeling, basically food poisoning. Perhaps some meats aren't being held at the correct temp and are going bad? I'm not sure. 


Not a good way to get this cheetah to come back. I am all for supporting small hole in the wall businesses, but not like this one. I hope things can be fixed, as this is a very convenient place to go for me but I feel I can't any longer. 

*growls*
author: Jei C.

description: Honestly the best sandwich for the price! It's authentic, full of meat and veggie, delicious and you can't beat the price!! The price and the authenticity makes it so worth it. You honestly can't find a Vietnamese sandwich for that cheap in sf anymore. The parking here can be difficult during busy hours but not unbearable. They also are cash only so make sure you stop by the bank first!
author: Cassandra D.

description:
The store front deserves some renovating because anyone walking by would be left confused at whether this store is actually in business or not. 

That aside, their Banh Mi blew me away. I unraveled that sandwich from its wrapper and was greeted by a pretty golden brown color. First bite, wow. Crunch, crunch. It was deliciously crunchy. How the heck? No other banh mi places ever had this amazing crunch. The only disappointing thing was that I order the #1 Combination Pork and there was very little meat in it. I did have a LOT of carrots though but the sauce was kind of dry or nonexistent. I came back again and was smarter and got the BBQ Pork (which I had meant to order originally but because my eyes saw combo pork and it was #1, I thought I was ordering the right one... HAHAHA... I need to learn to read the entire menu next time). The BBQ Pork was much more satisfying and for $4 + tax, WORTH IT!

Few seats to sit at but not sure if you want to sit here because there's really nothing to look at. Just grab it and go get some boba from Supercue and park yourself at the Parkside Square instead or something.
author: Diana C.

description:
What an experience!

I had come here today without any reservations about this place and left feeling like I made the right choice.

Located in the 1100 block of Taraval this cool spot makes some seriously good Vietnamese sandwiches. In having been to several other Vietnamese restaurants in the the Sunset and Richmond District I feel as though I have a good grasp of what a QUALITY sandwich is. And this place does and excellent job of creating awesome sandwiches. 

They also have milk tea as well which is a nice sweet treat to slurp or sip with your meal as well. I was going to get a honeydew tea from here but I just didn't have enough hands, next time!

Based on my observation I would believe that this place is a family owned business, possibly! I ordered the BBQ pork sandwich and then waited for awhile. There is some seating but not a lot. 

The prices here are perfect, especially if you happen to be a jobless college student or unemployed high school student looking for a cheap meal. $4 for a sandwich....doesn't get any better than that! 

My favorite part about coming here was being greeted with a smile and leaving to a smile. Whether or not it was genuine I appreciate the effort. That is what a call customer service. Going out of your way to acknowledge and greet customers is a HUGE deal for me. 

The sandwich was perfect! I would have liked some more BBQ pork in the sandwich but it wasn't a deal breaker for me. I could clearly tell that this place just gets SANDWICHES. Just a good merge of flavor in the sandwich. A round of applause is warranted for this place and their diligence in manufacturing great work! 

#cho tôi bit
author: Robert F.

description: I got the combination pork banh mi which was quite small compared to most Viet sandwiches from other places. The sandwich looked very flat, sad, and lacking of ingredients. The taste of the meat was fine, and the bread was crunchy, but lacked flavor. Overall presentation and flavor left a lot to be desired.
author: Edmund L.

description: I ordered the combo sandwich with white pork meat and Vietnamese ham.  It tasted very authentic because it came with pate. I like that the meat and veggies are very authentically Vietnamese meat and veggies instead of American chicken and sauce at some Vietnamese sandwich places. This place was as delicious as Little Paris, the sandwich shop I went to all the time as a kid. Glad to find a Vietnamese sandwich shop in the Sunset with reasonable prices!
author: Jennifer T.

description: Shrimp and tofu spring rolls are so good!
author: Lori M.

description:
This mom and pop shop is my go-to spot if I'm craving for a banh mi! They are reasonable priced at around $5 a banh mi, u can't beat that for a quick and delicious lunch! 

I always get the pan-friend chicken, sooooo goood! It takes about 3 minutes for them to make your sandwich, so you have time to walk around and collect pokeballs and shit at the nearby pokestops LOL.

Definitely recommend!
author: Jamila W.

description: I liked the sandwiches here. It's cheap and affordable. Although sometimes it comes out a little dry. They tend to use more fun than meat here. I had their shrimp rolls here before also, should be called skimp rolls. Tasted alright though. I would prefer Vikings at this point because it's higher quality and larger portions for the same price. This place is conveniently located though.
author: Alex C.

description:
Literally the best banh mi I've ever had.  Whenever I'm in San Francisco, I always visit the nice Asian man and order the BBQ pork banh mi!  Bread is perfectly toasted and everything in it tastes just as amazing. 

It does take about 10-15 mins for him to make the sandwich, but it's sooo worth it!
author: Katie K.

description: Sandwiches and rolls 10/10.  This is a hole in the wall place that I've been coming to, for years and the taste is always as amazing as the first time, so don't let the out exterior fool you. The food is amazing and the prices you can't beat. Sandwiches are nice and toasty with a good amount of filling, and it gets me full fast. I always go for the BBQ pork or the shredded pork sandwich and if I'm feeling more hungry I get the shrimp rolls, the sauce that goes with it is amazing!
author: Yeah O.

description: Solid option if you're in the area. The bbq pork is pretty delicious and a lot of places don't have the shredded pork spring rolls which are one of my favorite things. It's cash only though, so watch out for that.
author: Dexter H.

description:
Pork Combination has always been my go-to - I've been coming here since I was in middle school, simply because of its convenience. 

But over the years, I've definitely seen their quality go down... the bread still has a good crunch, but there's literally like 3 slices of meat in there & a some carrot pieces... and all while they've increased their prices.
author: Carrie L.

description: Moving to San Francisco made me really miss Vietnamese food. Coming from San Jose, I need my Vietnamese comfort food that's not a fusion or revamped Vietnamese cuisine. I've been to a lot of banh mi places and I don't trust them because they have crazy stuff like meatball banhmi, buffalo chicken banhmi??? Honestly, rule of thumb for me is that if they don't have one of the staple banhmi, I won't eat there. I always look for banhmi cha which is the porkroll sandwich. My favorite banhmi! It's simple and it tastes hella good but yet no one carries it. This is my go-to banhmi place that's so close to home. I will be coming here regularly :)
author: Anh N.

description: The best bahn mi me and my Vietnamese wife have had! The pork is the one to get, it was better than her combination meat. We can't wait to get back there!
author: ken k.

description: Constant low staffing with crazy lines. Friendly staff &  awesome Vietnamese coffee, well worth the wait!
author: Alyssa S.

description:
It's true that you can't really go wrong with a bahn mi--toasted bread, sauce, grilled meet, BAM tastiness.  (Or, should I go along with the wordplay and say BAHN?)  But with banh mi, there is indeed a fine line between just tasty vs. awesome, and Banhwich lies solidly in the ranks of awesomeness.

[BACKGROUND]

I used to work at the Safeway pharmacy nearby, and I would always be at a loss for what to eat for lunch.  Safeway pre-cooked food made from unsold groceries?  Eww.  Eating at a restaurant all by myself?  Forever alone.  However Bahnwich is the perfect place for a quick grab-and-go, and was also indulge-able--perfect at 1pm when you're hangry for lunch.

[NOMS]

I got the standard grilled pork banh mi, and every layer exceeded my expectation.
  
1. First of all, the bread tasted fresh and was incredibly flaky.  Despite making a mess, warm toasty baguette bread makes sandwiches magical.    

2. I was unimpressed when I saw the meat being microwaved, but just because you don't see this at other places doesn't mean it doesn't happen.  It ended up tasting alright--if it were grilled to order, it would take far longer, you'd run a higher risk of under-cooked food, and half of it would probably be burnt.   

3. The pate or whatever mystery sauce was used to slather the bread was savory and complex.  Although I can't assess the homemade-ness of the pate, at least it seems better than bottled mayo/ketchup/mustard of American sandwiches.

4. The crunchy assorted veggies were decent, with a shout-out to the thick layer of sliced carrots for adding the satisfying texture (and healthiness)

If you aren't in the sandwich mood, the plates look good and satisfying as well.

[INSTAGRAMABILITY]

The food is Instagramable, but everything else is definitely not... to be optimistic, I guess you could enjoy the ambiance of street food, but I would much rather take my food to-go.  Although the place doesn't look the best, I applaud the 92/100 health score, which exceeds many shiny-looking restaurants.

[THE MARKET]

Clearly, Banhwich dominates: one day I went to Guerra's Market & Deli and paid $9 for a sandwich, which I was far less satisfied with than the $3.50 Banhwich.  I guess Guerrra's has a nicer ambiance, but it doesn't matter because they don't have a seating area so you have to take your sandwich to-go anyways.  Guerrera may also have better service, but that doesn't matter either because I don't mind missing out on small-talk.
author: Edna C.

description:
Since we were in the neighborhood and had only a short amount of time for lunch we decided to grab banh mi at this little hole in the wall on taraval. I got the BBQ pork and my boyfriend got the combo pork. The BBQ pork was by far one of the best I've had in a long time. The pickled veggies were crisp and there was also cucumber in the banh mi which I've never seen before. I was also really excited they didn't have jalapeños in them, since I'm not really good with spicy food. The star of the sandwich though was definitely the bread. There's been so many times when I've gotten banh mi where the bread is ridiculously crusty to the point where it just hurts when you bite it. This bread was crispy on the outside but still soft and chewy on the inside and was the perfect balance. The combo pork banh mi wasn't bad, but I definitely would prefer the warm BBQ pork sandwich any day. 

Cons: $4 for a banh mi? I'm used to $2 banh mi in San Diego so this was kind of pricey for what it is, but the bread alone would make me come back. 

Ps: cash only! And a very small location so definitely better for take out orders
author: Sam L.

description:
they get busy!!!!  suggest  calling and ordering then come and pick up.

The BBQ Pork sandwich is awesome!   The pork is slightly dried, so the flavor is concentrated.  Must order.

There is no real place to sit, so this is a takeout recommended place.
author: Jerry W.

description: Don't let the store first impression fools you! This hole in the wall has one of the best Banh Mi sandwiches in town. The bread texture was crunchy on the outside and soft when you bite into it, the portion was great for the price. I ordered fresh rolls for the appetizer that was also excellent.
author: John H.

description:
16.09.28     1st visit


BBQ Pork Sandwich -------------------- 3 1/2  Good Sandwich at cheap price

At the age of basic banh mi sandwiches pricing above $4.75 as a average.
This place is one of the rare that is at $4 range AND still generous AND tasty.
The service is slow ... maybe he wasn't the main prep person. The lady showed up later.
      They have a single toaster oven (in the open area ... maybe there is another)
Using my PRICE+PORTION+TASTE criteria.
I would recommend this place.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
The service was good and I did not find the amount of meat lacking. I mention this because some older reviews noted otherwise.

Overall it was OK food. I agree with those who said it could use hot peppers. I give it a three because it isn't hard to find this kind of shop and there is no wow factor at this establishment.

I tried two sandwiches and really only liked one of the two. I would eat here again, but I would be tempted to try other places for lunch first.
author: Bryndon B.

description: bomb-digity! tofu banh-mi(sp?) is my favorite in the city. go there now
author: Coco M.

description:
Note: Their banh mis don't come with jalapeños, but they're available upon request!!! Just ask them when you order and they'll add it to your banh mi. 

I've only had the BBQ pork banh mi and it's great! Yes, it is true that their bread is amazing - hard on the outside but soft on the inside (that's what she said). The banh mi was fresh and made right before my very eyes - BBQ pork itself was flavorful. 

For $4 I thought that was pretty standard (actually cheaper than other Vietnamese shops in the city). Although nothing beats the good ol' Little Paris days on Clement where sandwiches were $3 or less.
author: Tee C.

description:
Eck. $4 for a banh mi with little meat and pickled veggies? No thank you. 
I was sorely disappointed with this dedicated banh mi shop. They skimped on the meat as well as the veggies; there were no jalapeños, and the bread was overpowering the sandwich. Not to mention it was much too flaky and crusty. 
Although it's kind of hard to get to, Saigon sandwich is a much more delicious treat. 
And it's cheaper too.

The ladies at the register were also alright, just bland and unenthusiastic. But I guess this place is decent if you're in a pinch for money and you're in the area. Otherwise, for the banh mi fanatics, take your money elsewhere :p
author: Nancy W.

description:
They make a delicious meatball sandwich. Their shrimp rolls are pretty good too. They don't put jalapeños in their sandwiches, and not sure if you can request it. I'm not a fan of jalapeños in sandwiches and always take them out at other places, so I can't comment on that aspect. They cut their sandwiches in half (yes, there are places that don't do that).

Seating is very limited but since most people take their orders to go, there is usually a spot to sit down and enjoy a bit of your sandwich. There are also boba places nearby if you want a drink with your sandwich.
author: James S.

description:
The sandwiches here are so cheap and affordable compared to many other places which keep raising their prices. 
The owner is so nice! 
I used to come here years ago but I stopped because it was not near where I lived but now a days I have been coming here for a quick meal.
author: Jenny L.

description:
This place is priced appropriately which is sooo rare in SF. 

Get some authentic vietnamese food, be super close to the beach, and help out a small business by coming here!
author: Miles M.

description: I love them and their sandwiches so much :') Nice service. CASH ONLY! Sitting space is a little tight, but who cares because the banh mi sandwiches are delicious. The bread is crunchy yet soft and their portions and prices are reasonable. It's my go-to place for my lunch breaks now :)
author: Cynthia T.

description:
I personally love this place! I have been getting sandwiches here after school all throughout high school. Every time I come here, it is always the same guy standing behind the counter watching tv thats over the cash register. Ahh, memories! 

I always get the combination pork sandwich, and it satisfies me every time. The toasty bread with pickled veggies and a combo of all sorts of pork is perfect for my taste. Their spring rolls are good too! Delicious and inexpensive: my favorite combo! But as for other things on the menu, I've never gotten them so I don't know how they taste. But from my own experience, this place would be my go-to place for Vietnamese sandwiches.
author: Julianne Z.

description:
Came here because I like punny phrases, and Banhwich is, tbh, pretty punny. Too bad the food tasted funny.. jk. Sorta. 

We ordered a chicken banh mi and two shrimp noodle rolls. The banh mi was good. The place is super small, so we watched the owner grill the chicken, toast the bread, and make the sandwich with his bare, ungloved hands.. Not bad tasting though. 

The shrimp noodle rolls were disappointing. The rice paper was too thick, there were literally 1.5 pieces of whole shrimp (they were cut into half so it looked like three whole shrimps in the package), the noodles were dry, and the rolls were just not very appetizing overall. 

I guess when a name of a restaurant has a specific menu item in it, just order that item and avoid the rest.
author: Samantha C.

description:
Earlier this week, my husband brought me a combination pork sandwich from this place. I got food poisoning from this sandwich!   I was sick the entire night and following morning. I swear the meat on this sandwich was "mystery meat."  I should have taken a photo. If you saw what the meat looked like, trust me, you would say the same. Just gross stuff.

Run...as fast as you can - far, far away from this place. Never again.
author: Gigi F.

description: I was curious what a $4 sandwich would be like. I got the combo pork.  It was basically a nice roll with some carrots and a couple slices of meat.  I'd recommend being a bit more generous with the protein.
author: Robert M.

description: If you look for a $4 sandwich that looks like a vietnamese sandwich, this place is for you. If you're really looking for some authentic sandwich, or better , just a decent sandwich, go somewhere else. Everything is pretty cheap but nasty. You will get cheated on quality. The vietnamese springrolls have a lot of missing ingredients, such as mint, peanit and cilentro. The peanut sauce is very watery. And these sandwiches? Same thing.. no daikon, no jalapenos. A lot of carrots with the wrong sauce, too sweet, too much vinaiger. The meat, porc or chicken is bad quality. You can find a lot of fat and skin,  it's really a sandwich that you can eat when you're starbiving for more than 30 days.
author: Jean-Yves F.

description:
Banhwich sells smoothies too so says the sign. banh mi is the main seller here. various combos. $3.50 plus .30 cents tax. Huh?

eats: pork combo banh mi (3.5 plus tax)
-mostly bread and shredded carrots (1/2 sammie was vingegared carrots), 5 thin slices of various pork cuts not tasted.
-mayo and some spices tasted, didn't taste jalepeno, pickles, cucumbers.
-1.5 stars, poor value

crumbs:
-sammies made to order, seemingly
-saw  lady cashier switch  a freshly made one for a premade one.
-not a good value, can buy 50 lbs of carrots for $6.
author: Victor G.

description: This place has good sandwiches, its a small mom and pop shop and the people who work there are super nice! i really like their crispy bread and combination sandwiches. Its cash only so make sure to bring cash! they have pretty good prices for their banh mi, i wish i lived close by, i would make this my main place to go to for vietnamese sandwiches!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Super small spot. 

Warm bahn mi, didn't have jalapeño though! I love jalapeño in my bahn mi. Good flavor and fresh bread. 

Spring rolls are my favorite. Soo fresh and the sauce was good. 

Lost a star for cleanliness. They should really clean this place up a lot more. I couldn't help but notice the clutter and old "spice display" under the chips on the wall.
author: Shivonne T.

description:
i used to come here all the time in high school (4+ years ago), and I thought it wasn't bad. Ugh but today....

First thing I see when I walk in - FLIES. Flies EVERYWHERE. It's gross. To the right, empty, dirty and some even broken plastic containers that looked like they held candy once upon a time. I was not greeted upon entering, and the lady seemed to have something against me already right when she saw me.

I ordered a sandwich and spring rolls, and she angrily said "you have to call in. I make now, you wait?" I told her I would wait. She threw a bun into the oven and went to the back. It doesn't take long to make spring rolls OR sandwiches, so I don't know why she was all pissed about it. There was literally nobody in there either-- so it's obvious that they weren't preparing anyone else's order.

It literally took 15 minutes to toast the bread. I had to go put more money in the meter because it was taking so long. They were just standing around waiting for the bread to heat up. She finished the spring rolls before the man even started making my sandwich.

This place is dirty, the people are rude, and the food isn't that great. They totally skimp on the meat. DO NOT RECOMMEND!
author: Erica A.

description:
I used to eat at Banhwich all the time in high school and I loved their shrimp spring rolls, however, it pains me to only be able to give them 3 stars. This place could easily get 4 or 5 stars with some small improvements. I'll start with what I really like about this place. 

The food is pretty good but I LOVE their green tea and lychee milk tea. Its not actually a milk tea but more like a milk slushy but it tastes really good! The smoothies are made from powder but somehow they make it taste fresh and delicious. Their food is also very reasonably priced. 

The problem with this place however is the guy who owns it never speaks or smiles. I order something and he just goes to the back and makes it or whispers something to the person working in the back. Sometimes I can't even tell if he heard my order or not. Moreover, the place has problems with cleanliness. The guy who handles the money also makes the sandwiches. I also saw a hair on one of the spring rolls they were selling in packets on the counter and told the guy so no one buys it and reports him. He just took it and threw it in the back without saying thank you or anything. I feel like if the guy working here just smiles and says thank you after your purchase once in a while and tried slightly harder to be cleaner, this place can be one of the best viet shops in sf. 

Overall, great spring rolls and great lychee and green tea milk smoothies. However, poor service and poor cleanliness.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Still love the food but HOURS ARE WACK. 

How are you gonna say you'll be open at 8 but have no sign of life at 8:30?? Many plans to bring lunch to work have been ruined... :(
author: Debra L.

description:
Banhwich is simply delicious. In a city where cheap food has become trendy and expensive, Banhwich has stuck with the tried and true formula. Their Vietnamese sandwiches have stayed simple, amazing, and affordable over the period of 10 years that I have been coming here. BBQ pork was my staple until I discovered the Tofu sandwich which had my attention for several years. Now I usually mix it up on the menu and get a variety of sandwiches, all of which are mouth watering.

The people who work here are kind and courteous, always adding a touch of love and home-cooked flavor to the food. If you want to eat at a real Banhwich place in the city, come here! I have tried all the "raved" about Banh Mi places in the city and trust me this is the most delicious!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: David W.

description: I've been here a few times. It's cheap, but the sandwiches are just okay, especially if you're comparing them to Irving Cafe and Deli http://www.yelp.com/biz/irving-cafe-and-deli-san-francisco#hrid:TlgPln_Pda03sN_CzbUXQQ/src:self. If I'm craving for a banh mi and I'm on Taraval, yeah I'll stop by.
author: Kylie L.

description:
This place is the shit.
Got the BBQ Pork sandy. It was DAMN delicious.
$4
We are half way thru 2016 and i can get a sandwich for $4, thats amazing.
Anyone complaining about price increases can suck one, "OH THEY RAISED THE PRICE OF THEIR SANDWICHES TO $4!!!! $4!!!!'
Im a big guy, that was plenty of sandwich for lunch.
Oh and if you ask for jalapeno, he will put it in your sandwich.
They know what a jalapeno is you just have to ask instead of wanting him to read your fucking mind.
*pro tip, have some sriracha on had to put on sandwich to really bring the thing together.
author: N O.

description:
My teenage boys LOVE this place and eat here regularly.  They think the pork bahn mi is the best they have had in the neighborhood by far. Extra star for the boys.

Me and the boys ordered the pork and the husband the fish cake.  Yum!  I won't say it is the best I have had but it was really good and the price was right.  My husband realy liked the fish cake.  I will ask for spicy next time.

As for the owner who handles the money and makes the sandwiches, he wore gloves when making our sandwiches, I like that!
author: Lydia K.

description:
A fellow Yelper recommended I come here. 
And for the most part, I'm glad I did. It's good to explore, right?

First off, lets not kid anyone, this place looks and probably is kinda dirty. 
San Francisco Health Inspection Score = 86 or 88 (it's on the wall to your right when you enter)
You can draw your own conclusions from that. 

Anyhoo, as I walk in, the sandwich man was wiping down the counter with his bare hands, flicking captured food particles onto the floor, and wiping his hands across his chest, with his finger tips grazing his armpit region. 

Niiice. Working class folks, I can dig it. My favorite kinda peeps. 

I order a BBQ Pork sandwich. 
He gives me a nod, doesn't wash his hands, slips on a torn plastic glove with the thumb part missing, and begins preparing my sandwich... Hmmm...

I glance back at the health inspection score and then back to sandwich man.

"It's ok," I think to myself... Anthony Bourdain's been through worse. 

Few minutes later, I get my sandwich. 

I take a bite.. Hmmm. Not bad. 
I ask for sriracha. 
MmmMMm better.  

It tasted okay. Not great, but good enough. 

6 hours later... I'm practically peeing outtah my butt....  :X

*Le Sigh*

I'll give this place another shot in the near future and see if my butt explodes again.
author: Garland W.

description:
Really just a review of the Iced Coffee....

I can't tell you how many times i've been to this spot, too many to count... And all just for the Vietnamese Iced Coffee. They do other other plates & sandwiches, but sadly I've never ordered anything else but the Vietnamese Iced Coffee. 

Really glad I found this spot, VIC is my favorite coffee, and not too many places have it or even do it well...
author: Teena Marie T.

description: This small restaurant tucked away on Taravel is a good option for a quick bite. We got the combo pork and the BBQ pork. You can't really go wrong with pork. They were both tasty and the pickled veggies also added more flavor. What really stands out here is the bread. I always end up cutting my mouth when I eat banh mi because I assumed it to be the price you pay. However, that did not happen this time because although the exterior of the bread was hard and crispy, the inside was very soft and gentle on the mouth. I would eat here again. Cash only.
author: Peter H.

description:
Located on the busy Taraval Street, you're lucky if you're able to find a street parking!  There are many shops and a few market places so the street is quite busy.

This is not your sitdown type of place.  It's very small (somewhat dirty) so it's a order-to-go/pick-up place for Banh Mi sandwich.  There is only a table in the corner, but, I personally wouldn't sit there to eat.  =O

We ordered the BBQ pork and BBQ chicken banh mi  sandwiches.  They are pretty good.  I liked the bread toasted...gives the sandwiches a little extra crunch!

I don't think I'll come back again, just because the place is kinda dirty.  Luckily I didn't come down with tummy ache.  LOL

The owner should ramp up and tidy up this place!  I think that could bring more business!  Cleaniness is important!!
author: Jenny Y.

description:
I've tried a couple of different sandwiches, and I like most of them. I most recently had fancy pork banh mi (cha lua). The bread was toasted but not overtoasted. It was perfect... not so hard that it hurts the roof of your mouth when you bite into it. The price was great! It was three bucks for fancy pork.

I also usually get shrimp spring rolls... they are delish and only $3.50. (I saw the same thing for much smaller at Out the Door for $8!)

The place itself is small... has a couple of stools, but not really a place to hang out and chill. It's more of a take out place. They take a little longer to prepare the food than I am used to. I'd give it 3.5 stars but I'll bump it up to 4 stars for the great prices and for the nice man behind the counter.
author: Lani S.

description:
Stopped by as we were in the neighborhood. Our usual banh mi shop is on Irving.

Order was for one combination and one BBQ pork sandwich to go. When we got our sandwiches home, we found we had ywo combo sandwiches and no BBQ pork. Too hungry to go back, we dug in.

The bread is softer than the standard baguette roll and there was too much bread to meat ratio. I couldn't really taste much of the pate and there wasn't much spread of any kind on the bread.

I might come back in a real pinch, but would continue to go with my usual place.
author: P K.

description:
Not too many places that serves Vietnamese sandwiches under $8 in the city these days, so I was surprised when I came across this place. It's a tiny hole-in-the-wall mom & pop's store and looks a bit dingy but pretty good. There's maybe 4 stools to eat your sandwich at a counter but not much room past that. Sandwiches are made to order, so you do have to wait a bit as well.

My order:
Banh Mi Dac Biet (Combination pork)
Banh Mi Thit Nuong (BBQ pork)
Cafe Sua Da (iced Vietnamese coffee)

The bread had a nice crunch and great flavors in the meats. The cafe sua da wasn't strong enough in my opinion so I wouldn't order that again. Just stick to the sandwiches.
author: Kitty K.

description: My sis had the banh mi pate and I had steamed rice noodle.  Both hit the spot!! Plenty meat & ultra cheap.  More parking if u can make it for lunch.
author: Fong L.

description: 3.5. Delicious bread and fresh ingredients. Number 8 bbq chicken....very nice. My only complaint....the sandwich was in desperate need of chilies.   Fast, friendly service.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Total hole in the wall - almost literally!!

Fresh, soft and crisp bread, lots of vegetables and generously laden with chicken, my chicken banhmi sandwich was pretty darned tasty and perfectly priced.

Very no frills type of place and they warmed up my chicken in the microwave. However, something about the place reminded me of days long past and the food was tasty enough for me (not a banhmi lover) to plan on returning for some more.
author: Shinny L.

description:
good place to get a bahn mi in the sunset.

I was craving a banh mi on my way to the beach on a rare sunny day in SF, yelp'd this place and glad i found it.  I ordered two bbq pork and a combo pork and both were delicous.  I know where to get my banh mi's in the sunset now.
author: Donovan R.

description: Awful. for a banh mi, there is no meat!!! I was hoping it would be good since it's in my neighborhood, walkable distance. I always believe in second chances. First time I ordered a combo, there was just one slice of meat! Second time, I ordered a pate sandwich. They are so stingy they didn't even put pate to the edge of the bread. It's just a small sliver of pate on both sides. Most places also give you jalapeños and pickled daikon. they should change the name to STINGY MI. Not coming back. I just wanted to be kind and give two stars because it didn't taste bad.
author: Elisa M.

description: Cheap and fantastic Banh Mi's. Mainly just a takeout place though.
author: Uddhav A.

description:
I had a HUGE craving for a vietnamese sandwich. Maybe it was pent up emotions from that hot girl from the Nom Nom Truck on The Great Food Truck Race or that lengthy talk i had with my friend about the best sandwiches in San Francisco. Anyway, i had a craving and luck was not on my side.

It was 6:20. I has hungry. I needed a viet sandwich. I was confident and cocky that my favorite place, Irving Cafe + Deli (which is much better than saigon sandwich because of the pate) would be open for another couple of hours and able to satisfy. Unfortunately, it closes at 6:30. I dialed up a couple more places and they all close at 6:30 as well...at last, i found Banhwich that is nearby and closes at 7. 

The reviews for this place looked okay but since i never heard of it, i had my doubts. Going in, i see this old man who was ready to close up shop. I ordered 2 combination pork sandwiches, waited 5 minutes for my French Bread (not traditional vietnamese  sandwich bread) to get toasted and excitedly went home to try out the hot sandwich...and here is what i thought of it:

Good Points:

1. owner was nice
2. meat and other condiments were put on carefully and everything was in place
3. $3.50 for a combination pork...slightly bigger than normal

Bad Points:

1. Bread was dry. (it needed the traditional viet bread)
2. pate (my favorite part of a viet sandwich) lacked flavor
3. got cold within 5 minutes of receiving the order
4. meat and everything else was just ok

Overall impression:

1. despite the neat presentation, the sandwich lacked quality
2. none of the meat items were great, especially the flavorless pate
3. at $3.50, the price was standard
4. the bread was a major downfall

Bottom Line:

- this sandwich reminded me of how cheap a viet sandwich is to make. I know that most places, if not all places use prepacked meats but i could taste it here with every bite. maybe the lack of customers means that the meat i ate was very very old.
- it did not satisfy my craving and because of this experience, i am worried that my next viet sandwich will also disappoint (maybe the super deliciousness was all in my head). 
- unfortunately, this place turned me off from viet sandwiches for a while
author: Simon L.

description:
Let me start this out by saying that I may be a bit biased, having spent the last few years on Saigon Sandwiches. down in the TL.

Sandwich was okay. Tofu was missing some flavor and the meatball had good flavor, but seemed to be missing something else. Not sure. Seems like there should have been a "secret sauce" added that wasn't there. Bread was too toasted, so it made the sandwich a bit too crumbly. Also had a pearl tea (which I thought was supposed to be a pearl milk tea, but which turned out to be a pearl almost frozen liquid tea). But I can't complain too much about the mango or green tea ones aside from the extra freeziness of them.

Overall first impressions? I still love this place. Must be the name. It's fun to say. BANHWICH. Say it with me.... bahhhhnnnnnwich. Just sounds good.

We also got a tofu spring roll on the recommendation from Yelp. Couldn't finish that, so will have to give this post an update later this afternoon.
author: K. C.

description:
I first discovered this place when my brother took me,  at the time when he went to Lincoln High School. Hands down one of the best mango tapioca I have ever had, and trust me I have had lots of mango tapioca ;) 
You can really taste the mango, and the BBQ pork banh mi is to die for!!!
My only question is why have you not gone yet?
author: Alyssa G.

description: I love this place. I have been coming for years now and never get tired of it. The bread is always nice and crunchy, but not too hard. I recommend the pan fried chicken banh mi. The chicken is nice and tender. One of the best banh mi I have ever had. The price is not expensive but not the cheapest either. It's $4 for a banh mi, which I think is reasonable.
author: Justin H.

description:
Best place to get a "homemade" feel Vietnamese sandwich. I've been going here for the past couple of months now, and every sandwich I've had has never failed to keep me content. The guy working there is super chill and down-to-earth. I usually leave him a tip every time; a little generosity for him having to work at his shop every day. 

I highly recommend getting the BBQ Pork Banh Mi.
author: Ej P.

description:
Solid banh mi sandwiches in a little hole in the wall place in West Portal. The pork is great, the chicken not bad. Those are the only ones we tried. My ratometer score below:

Meat quality: 4/5
Bread quality: 5/5
Size for value: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Speed: 4/5
Ambiance: There is none
author: Tom K.

description: Good place to grab a viet sandwich for the low low. Usually tip him a few bucks cuz the price is right
author: Kevin C.

description:
I really, REALLY wanted to like this place.

The guy was rubbing his chin in a thoughtful manner when I came in to order. He used that same hand to handle my bread and put it in the toaster oven. The germs will cook off, right?

He put one glove on one hand, then proceeded to scratch his arm with the gloved hand.

Then came the eye rubbing, Deal breaker.

Before he started assembling the sandwich, I asked him if he could wash his hands, in a friendly, gentle-reminder kind of voice...he looked at me like I just kicked a puppy and disappeared into the back room, past the sink in view. 

I left without the germ sandwich.
author: Stretchmark S.

description:
I dare you to find a meal for under $4.00. DARE. You could add a drink and a small bag of chips for an excellent combo for not much more. Or even better, walk a couple of blocks and get some boba from Quicklys.

The BBQ Pork Combo is their signature sandwich. It's a lot of awesome for the punch. There's really not much more to say. Fresh quality sandwiches at an unbeatable price.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Finally! a pretty decent and solid banh mi place that is NOT located in busy-as-hell Irving street in the Sunset Area! This tiny ass place is located on Taraval street, where the parking is leagues easier to find that the accursed Irving street, where more Fobs hang out than a KTV bar. I am the Prince of Taiwan, and I love my people..but we have to find more places to hang out than just Irving street in the Sunset Area. 

Prices are good, from 3 bucks to about 3.50 for the tasty Vietamese sandos. I think the service is a tad slow, but I think that is because the dude makes it from scratch. I haven't yet tried the Iced Sace sua de, but from all the accolades here, I think it will probably blow me away too.
author: Jerry C.

description: So I think this place deserves 5 stars but you have to understand the expectation.  This is a quick cheap bite you take back to the park or wherever you are headed.  This is not the restaurant you take you family to for a sit down meal.  The owners have been so nice to us every time we go there.  We've tried a bunch of things here and the food has been good..i mean not the most amazing I've ever had but really good for a little joint like this (in fact it converted my bf into a banh mi sandwich lover).  It's still cheap where others have raised their prices.  You do have to order jalapenos specifically to get them on the sandwich.  But all in all, we come here all the time because it's such a good, easy going place.
author: Sharra C.

description: I used to live down the street from this place and I literally came here everyday after school for sandwiches, spring rolls and Thai iced tea. They have good food at great prices and they are also the cutest little family ever!
author: Natasha D.

description:
Another neighborhood place we frequent. Being creatures of habit we always order the BBQ chicken banh mi. They've improved on the pickled carrots and cucumber slices. Evenly distributed in the sandwich. You can also request jalapeno peppers in your sandwich. 

We always place our order over the phone, and within minutes, it's ready for pickup. 

Sometimes it can get hectic if you come in person because it's a very small mom & pop operation as already stated. 

Note:  Try to avoid coming when Lincoln H.S. students are out & about. They've got open campus so students flock to Taraval St. during the lunch hour that starts around 11 a.m.  Most students are courteous, but others are oblivious and tend to block the sidewalk.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Although I'm in the area about 4 times a week, I was never ever interested in ordering a sandwich here. There were just a lot of factors that initially turned me off from this place: the Lincoln HS students frequent this place... actually, that's pretty much it.

Anyway, decided to randomly give this a try... and surprise! Surprise! It's not bad! In fact, it was actually good. The bread was perfectly toasted and warm and the BBQ pork was quite tasty. This sandwich would be even better if it had tad more acid and less fat. Actually, just thinking about this sandwich has me craving (yes, I said "craving") another one. 

Taste is 3-stars but I'm giving it a 4-star because Banhwich has a high return factor. As in, I will be coming back for the BBQ sandwiches frequently.
author: Erin M.

description:
In the Sunset, I think this is the best place to get Vietnamese sandwiches.

I normally get BBQ Chicken and it costs less than $4. I usually call in so by the time I get there, I can just pay and go.

There's nothing incredibly special about them, but you shouldn't expect that for $4. It has everything you would expect in them and they taste good, which is why I come here a lot.
author: Derek M.

description: Cheap bánh mì in a tiny place. It's good. I've definitely had worse. It's fast. I've definitely had slower. It's cheap. Well, if I can only find that place in C-town that was cheaper. It's closer to home than dinosaurs, which is better I must say. A lot of people complain about the cleanliness. I try to not notice in such places. It makes life easier, but I noticed. Oh well. Good location for me and cheap. The bread is fresh and so are the ingredients. Very important.
author: Rich M.

description: Although small and usually empty, this is my favorite place to satisfy my Vietnamese sandwich cravings. The bread has the perfect texture of crunch and soft, the meat is always edible and full of flavor, and I just keep coming back! I hope this place gets more business so it doesn't shut down, I would hate to settle for one of the other 50 places I have tried!
author: Antonio J.

description: My friend and I decided to go to the Sunset District to get some grub. We were deciding if we wanted to get pho or banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich) so I checked Yelp and this was the closest location where we were about to get off. Checked the menu, decided to eat here, I ordered number 5 which was the Cha Lua banh mi sandwich. - Definitely good! I would come back again. Worker making the sandwich is nice and welcoming. He makes the sandwich in front of you and by that you can tell they're not sketch. ;)
author: Lauren Y.

description: I always get the combo banh mi. The sandwich itself has one of the best fillings I've tasted. The only problem I have is how hard the bread is. They toast it for so long that the bread cuts the roof of my mouth (not good...). Overall, the banhwiches are affordable and taste good. Just ask them not to toast it as much.
author: AJ C.

description:
Cheap eats! I love eating banh mi (Vietnamese sandwiches)! At $3.50 a sandwich its as good as it gets when you want a quick bite.

Since its opening around 2004, I have come here often for nibbles to-go. There's only one person working, so be patient. It may take up to 20 minutes for your sandwich depending on customers that day. 

I'm still a fan after so many years. Yum! Try it!
author: Amy C.

description:
I had a craving for a Vietnamese right when this place had opened an was lazy to walk up to 19th and Taraval. So I came here and order some Pho to go and even though I was the only person in there at noon it still took awhile. The place was so small that there was one table for 4.

When I got home to eat my Pho, the sprouts were old and the soup taste like can soup with more salt. I heard their sandwiches were even worst not enough filling to make a decent sandwich with half the bread. 

Their friends always be coming here to visit them. One drove a gold Camry and couldn't drive. Lady made a illegal U-turn from the inside lane and struck me. Lucky for me a witness seen what happened, lying old woman.
author: M C.

description: Where's the beef?? No jalapeños , very little cilantro. Don't believe the hype
author: Sean D.

description: I used to come here a few times a week, my faves were the combination pork & the bbq. Dinosaur on ocean has a better tofu sandwich though. The guy who makes the sandwiches is quiet and takes his time, which I like. I've moved from sf, and I can't seem to find my viet sandwich replacement. This place is also super cheap & cash only
author: Monica A.

description:
Taraval is teemed with Chinese and Italian-neither seemed appetizing to me.  

After walking for a while, I finally found Banhwich @ the same time all the students let out for their lunch, fabulous, but they only order the premade, so no problemo!!!  

Bun Na Nuong for $5.50, plenty of lettuce under the noodles & lots of grilled chicken!  

Chopstick report: the nice rounded ones, not the ones you break apart.
author: Cynthia C.

description: So I pass by this place a lot of times since I live in the area but never gave this place a try. Just this once I came here instead of my favorite place at the Irving Cafe. I ordered a fancy pork and pate for myself and a combination to go. There was only one guy who worked that day and his customer service was average to below average which ironically reflected on the sandwich. The one thing that really bothered me about the sandwich was the bread. It was very very dry and flaky that it made me choke and cough. I don't think the bread should be toasted that long. Anyways, the ingredients were alright but it just wasn't that good. I rather pay $4 at my favorite place at the Irving Cafe.
author: Carmen L.

description:
I absolutely love this place. I used to come here everyday when I attended school a few blocks away from there. The Banh Mi is made fresh, it's not pre-made. The owner is very nice also, I would call him, "Mr. Cool". 

What he does is that he toasts the bread for a good 2 minutes, and he prepares the meats and he does his thing! What I like about this place is that they prepare everything fresh, except for the Spring Rolls. Everything is basically good here, I love this place.
author: cadence p.

description:
Been coming here for a while now. From my experiences, the place is good when they are not too busy, but not as good when they are busy.

When they aren't busy, they toast the bread correctly and they add the right amount of meat and veggie toppings. Otherwise the kind of randomly toast the bread and don't give you enough meat or toppings. So you kind of take your chances. I usually drop by when I get a craving. 

The banh mi's at Irving Cafe are a little better:

http://www.yelp.com/biz/irving-cafe-and-deli-san-francisco

PS. The rice shrimp/beef rolls are actually pretty tasty, and the sauce is good too.
author: Dom L.

description: Pretty cheap for the sandwhich, best for on the go snack! One of the best viet sandwhiches in the city! #7 is BBQ Pork, which is really yummy.
author: Nancy W.

description:
They make some good vietnamese sandwiches here!

It's a little hole in the wall type place run by some very friendly peeps...

The set up is real simple and the guy who makes the sandwiches is quick and fast.

I ordered the combo pork sandwich and it was pretty tasty for just $3...can't beat that!

They also make spring rolls with the noodles and shrimp inside..my fave!

There is like one table in there and it's tight quarters..but if you're in the mood for a quick V sandwich..this is the place to go!
author: Jade B.

description:
Came here a few times after school. Their bread is toasted right when you order, it's crispy on the outside but soft on the inside. I ordered the BBQ pork every time and they put lots of pork in. Great price for the amount of pork they put in. 

Once you order, the start to toast the bread. When the bread is toasted they start making it right on the spot and they're pretty fast about it.

Great place to go after school if you're hungry and want to quickly grab something to eat.
author: Hanna T.

description: Hidden gem. Hole in the wall. No ambiance. But the pork special sandwich is sooo delicious. Every time I'm in the neighborhood and can find parking, I stop to get my fix. It's definitely a take-out place. Price point is excellent. Family run. They seem sweet.
author: Cynthia L.

description: I work a few blocks from this place and am a big fan of Vietnamese Sandwiches so when I discovered this spot I was stoked. At a glance it doesn't look like much of a place but the nice man that owns the place and works at the counter is always friendly, makes yummy sandwiches and eventually remembers your favorite items. Mine is the BBQ Chicken Banh Mi with extra Jalapenos! It is so addicting and for a price under $5 you can't beat it. They buy all of their bread from the French Bakery next door so it is extremely fresh. I later found out the bakery and the deli is owned by the same family. Both of these businesses are awesome and very reasonably priced. I always recommend my clients to eat there afterwards. They also do these spring roll trays that I love to get for parties... sooooo good.
author: Ashley T.

description: Value.  To be honest, I'm not a superfan of banh mi's, but this is where I go when I want something cheap, fast, and not crappy chain fastfood.  Folks here are nice and like I said, 7-8 bux for 2 sandwiches is a winner winner chicken dinner.  My personal fav - grab 2 sandwiches before heading off to the Academy of Sciences or SF Zoo with my son = easy, cheap lunch and no waiting in crazy lines in a cafeteria with a child.
author: Tim L.

description:
The owner is a sweet, friendly guy.

I think the sandwiches are yummy and have good prices.  I've also tried both types of spring rolls, egg rolls, Thai Iced Tea, and a Vietnamese dessert.  They were generally good, especially for the prices.

Happy to support this place.
author: Thuan N.

description: I love banh mi's and am quite hesistant to steer away from my usual (Cafe Bunn Mi and Saigon Sandwiches)...but since I was introduced to this place by my sister in-law, and to my surprise, the sandwiches are pretty tasty.  I've tried both the chicken and the pork and they are your standard taste.  The thing I like about this place is that their bread is light and airy (not too much bread like Little Paris).  Plus, it's cheap and close to home.  Minus 1 star for the questionable cleanliness...
author: Lisa W.

description: I love going here for a sandwich. The beef combo is good, and its very reasonable price 3.50. I tried their thai ice tea nd it's flavorful! (: yummm. The owners are nice and very quick.
author: Sandy C.

description:
I understand that sometimes in life, you'll have a banhmi craving and it must be satisfied. You might find yourself in this neck of the woods, at Banhwich with no other choice at hand.

I mean, it's OK, it really is ok. But ugh the bread.... the bread... might just be old bread that's toasted. A bit hard and brittle that it cuts up the roof of your mouth. The fillings for the combo are decent and the folks are nice people, but can't they get rid of the flies?
author: Faffy L.

description:
Love the name....was craving for a vietnamese sandwich and decided to give this place a try!

I had the chicken and my bf ordered the meatball and combo. He loved the combo, however the meatball was just ok. My chicken was tasty and I love how they use fresh veggies and the overall taste of the sandwich was good, I have had better. 

From what my friends tell me I paid too much...4.00-4.50/sandwich

Still have yet to try Saigon sandwiches....
author: Michelle Y.

description: Ew. The tofu banh mi was gross. The sauce was bitter and unpleasant. Also, the staff was a bit rude. They acted miffed that I wanted to eat in (it was empty and the counter was sticky) and that I asked for a glass of water.
author: L M.

description: Great fish cake sandwich; tofu and chicken sandwich are good too.  friendly service, great prices.
author: Benny A.

description:
I've discovered this place a few weeks ago from driving by and decided to try it out two separate occasions.

  Both occasions, the gentleman working I assume is the owner, which I guess is like a Mom and Pop's type of store. I ordered of course a Vietnamese sandwich, which was priced at $3.50, but after taxes it equaled between $4.30-4.70 ish, which kind of upset me. Because for some reason I swear I learned that food products are not suppose to be taxed especially when I'm getting it to go. 

  The wait time for the sandwich literally takes at least 5 minutes and that's quite long when I was the only customer there both times, and for a sandwich that wasn't all that delicious, and was just alright.

  I prefer going to the Vietnamese sandwich place on 22nd ave - 22rd ave and Irving instead with it's price priced at what it is without the damn tax and for a better quality Vietnamese sandwich with less wait time.
author: Pudgy G.

description:
I would give this place a 5 star because they're food is great and the prices are even better! The reason I give it 4 is because they ran out of tofu twice on me =( 

They make really good Tofu sandwiches and tofu spring rolls, the best I've ever had. Perfect for vegetarians. They also have really good vermicelli or ho fun noodles with chicken. 

I recommend this place if your hungry and need to pick something up quick.
author: Kristin M.

description: $5.80 for combo bun (cold rice noodle), $3.50 for bang mi combo pork (sandwich), and $3.50 for cold shredded pork rolls. Wow! The cook/cashier/only person in the store was MIA initially and doesn't speak English. He took quite awhile to cook. Imagine if you were cooking at home. It's like that kind of time. I think that he forgot to close the door because it's 5pm and they close at 3pm according to yelp.
author: Caitlyn K.

description: I love Vietnamese sandwiches...and their Banh Mi Xui Mai is one of my favorites!  The tomato sauce reminds me of my mom's and you can't find many places that make it that way.  Whenever I'm around the area, I always make an effort to stop by to get one even though I may not be hungry.  The bread is so crunchy and soft.  Their banh uoc and five spice chicken over rice noodles are also delicious...actually, I can't think of anything I've ordered here that I don't like!
author: Trung N.

description: Sometimes, when something is almost perfect, there is nothing much to say than just that. BBQ pork banh mi rocks my world. The only reason this place doesn't get full marks from this happy customer is due to their early closing times.
author: Jane K.

description: I have been eating here for 5+ years. It's hands down the best Bahn Mi and one of the best sandwiches in the city ! If you haven't been, YOU ARE MISSING OUT...get the BBQ pork sandwich, ASAP
author: Reuben R.

description: Decent banh mi for a very low price, they offer chips and drinks (they make tapioca drinks too) to go with your sandwich, a meal for two was less than $11. The establishment is really small and kind of grimy, not enough space for a large group tp eat there.
author: Karen D.

description: Small place but I love the stream rice noodle with bbq chicken! Love the sauce too! Great price and always open early in the morning. Five stars :)
author: Kimberlie M.

description:
Food: 3/5
service: 5/5  just the owner/cashier man. But hes very nice.

This place has bahn mi, spring rolls, vermicelli, drinks, and an assortment of other vietnamese foods. I usually get the sandwiches which are about $3.50 depending on what kind you get. The price is good, but the sandwiches are a bit on the small side compared to other bahn mi I have eaten. The BBQ pork meat is very good though.
There are two old looking tables and some bar stools with a ledge near the window. This is definitely a take out place and not eat in. 
You go to the counter and order what you want and the cashier/owner makes the sandwich for you on the spot. You pay after you get your sandwich. The spring rolls, vermicelli, and rice dishes are prepacked on styrofoam plates so you pick those up from counter and pay for them.
The place is bit messy, and that might turn some people away. There are paper bags stacked up in the corner and some old magazines on a rack. It looks like some asian person's house with a cash register rather than a restaurant.
author: Cecile S.

description: I'm a big fan of this sandwich shop! Every time I'm in the area, I get myself the Fish Cake sandwich, and it never disappoints! Sometimes, I end up buying myself two because it's THAT good (or, the fact that I have the metabolism of a 14 year old boy). Either way, if you're ever in the area, you seriously need to check out this place! Definitely a great hole-in-the-wall establishment!
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I ordered a meatball sandwich, which is pretty much my favorite so far, all thanks to Irving cafe. Only thing is, it's not as great as Irving cafe. The meat is soft and juicy, but it doesn't have the garlicky flavor that Irving have. Everything else about it is great and the roll that they used is deceivingly soft. Crunchy outside with fluffy bread inside. I also tried the Shrimp rolls (or whatever it's called) and that is good stuff! 

Quick bite without the pinching the wallet too hard? Why not. It's not bad for what you pay for.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
5 Starts just because it's such a small mom and pop operation just like what my parent's have back home in sacramento. 
I was CRAVING a Vietnamese sandwich for like a week now and most places close at like 4! What's up with that?! 
Anyways the sandwich hit the spot. The bread wasn't the french bread I was used to but you know what it was frickin good! Got the pork combination #1! 
the man who made it for me was so sweet and when I asked if I could just have a steamed pork sandwich he just smiled and said "yes we have bbq pork" haha sweet man.
author: Lisa H.

description: They actually make pretty good sandwiches. However, the place itself is a little old and dirty. They should clean it up or do something to make it more decent. I usually order to-go and not eat there because it's small and I dont think I want to sit around there. They do toast the bread and the fillings are pretty decent. The price is decent and it usually satisfies my banh mi fix.
author: Linda H.

description: ive been trying Vietnamese sandwiches around SF and i still have yet to find one better than the bbq pork bahn mi at this place. this place sells my all time favorite sandwich.
author: Dylan F.

description:
Happened to be walking by and checked out their menu and I saw that their Vietnamese sandwiches were priced from $3 to $3.25 so I decided to grab one and check it out.  

I'm always down to try a place once and this will probably be one of those spots.  It's not terrible mind you.  But it's one of things where you crave something, then have a substandard version of what you were craving and then now, your craving gets even stronger.  You all know you've been there before.  

They just don't put enough filling in there.  Meat was skimpy and even the pickled veggies.  I felt I was eating just bread for the most part.  Looks like I'm gonna have to make my way to Saigon sandwiches in the TL again soon.....
author: Mark W.

description:
Hopefully this isn't the best I can get on Taraval.  The bbq chicken sandwich is nothing special, and I was still hungry afterwards.  There was only one guy working, and three people in front of me, so it took a little while to get my order filled.

That said, the sandwich did hit the spot.  Maybe I should just order two next time?
author: Jenny L.

description:
Divert your line of vision away from the meth lab-looking kitchen (I know it's difficult to do so when the kitchen is right behind the register, but try your best to focus on, say, the drink refrigerator on your left - like I do) and this place is the holy grail of "I'm-a-student-on-a-serious-budget" cheap eats. Whenever I wander past this joint I scrounge for whatever change I have in my bag to pay the $3.80 for their bomb shrimp summer rolls. Friends and acquaintances alike know that I have the appetite of a horse, and i can feel satisfied after eating just these rolls.

But remember, don't let those eyes wander past the register or you'll probably lose your appetite.
author: Marianne C.

description: good banh mi....sandwiches are on point and prices are right.. Don't see anything wrong with it
author: Wallace W.

description:
The Vietnamese sandwiches here so cheap! I've tried almost all their sandwiches here. They're ok-good. I've had better. But for these prices, I'll come when I'm craving a V. sandwich. They also have tapioca drinks, those colorful jelly V. drinks with beans, and spring rolls here.  I like the bbq pork spring rolls.

FYI: I don't know why but they charge tax on the spring rolls. They come with peanut sauce. It's good but soooo watered down. 

Parking is a pain if you have to pay for a meter. But I suggest parking a bit further down (NOT on Taraval) and look for free parking. 

If you're in a hurry, call in your oder. That way you don't have to wait for him to make each sandwich.

I don't come here on weekdays so I don't know how bad the crowd is from Lincoln High School. I can NOT stand teenage kids so I do my best to avoid them.

If you're coming here, it's to fill up cheap on something good.  The BBQ Pork sandwich with chips and a drink are like, 4 bucks or something.  The sandwiches are consistently good, but you have to catch them mid day or something.  They used to close early when I lived around the corner.  The man and the lady who work there are sweet too.  And let's be honest, it's got to be 1000 times better than the Taco Bell/ KFC across the street.
author: Patrick J.

description:
One of my first ever threads on Yelp was the Search For the Best Vietnamese Sandwich in SF... 
http://www.yelp.com/topic/san-francisco-vietnamese-subs-in-sf#0Eth8YqETPkijou6U8uqiQ

(Yes, I did get a professional smackdown by Hao on that thread... 
Oh, those were the days. )

Sadly, this isn't one of them. It fits the bill when I need to grab lunch during my 30 minute lunch break when I'm working down the street- seriously, who decided 30 minutes was enough for lunch, anyway? 

$3 gets you a BBQ chicken sandwich, (50 cents cheaper than Little Saigon off of Clement) but the flavors just aren't there... the right Vietnamese Sandwich is something I *crave* and will eat with reckless abandon- again, this isn't one of them. 

Parking in the area is easy, going during lunch hours during the school year is a *bad idea* (LINCOLN HS is right up the street,) as mentioned by fellow yelpers here. 
(Thank you to fellow yelper who PM'd me that the High school in question is NOT Lowell, but is in fact LINCOLN!) 

NOTE: they close at 3PM on Tuesdays.
author: M'ia K.

description: vietnamese sandwiches (bahn mi) served on a warm crusty french roll with fresh shredded carrots, cilantro, and choice of meats are the featured item here. my favorite is the pate. prices cannot be beat. ranging from $2.20 to $2.75. the shrimp roll is tasty as well served cold with rice noodles, mint, and lettuce. i still liked the bahn mi that Lam 's Cafe used to serve before shutting down a little better but now this is the only place in the hood serving this item. good, not outstanding.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Millions of Americans suffer from laziness and unwillingness to cook. Don't let that get in the way of your life. Introducing Bahnwich. 

Before I met Bahnwich, I had sunk so low, I was resorting to frozen foods. Eating had become a task and it was taking it's toll on my soul. And then one day, I looked out the window from the L and there was Bahnwich, looking inviting and tasty and, best of all, affordable! So I walked in and got myself a sandwich and things turned around. I started feeling like myself again. 

If you are suffering from laziness and unwillingness to cook, ask your doctor about Bahnwich.
author: Kit S.

description: Pretty good, but expensive compare to lee's. And I dont like the old lady there, she let someone cut me when I was patiently waiting.
author: Thuy O.

description: The sandwiches here are pretty good; however, it takes a really really long time to make. The prices arent too expensive. Range from $3.00 to $3.50 for a sandwich. If the sandwiches were made faster, this place would be awesome!
author: James L.

description:
This place not only has received the symbol of excellence(99 rating!) from SF Dept of Public Health, which if you know Taraval, well lets just say that is quite a miraculous feat...they serve pretty darn good banh mi for less than $3.  Sure this isn't top-notch like Saigon Sandwich shop, but did i say the bread was perfectly toasted and not the standard bagette size.

We are talking a bun that rivals the size of ur standard dutch-crunch, but with the same french/vietnamese flavor happenin.  I went with the pate and guzzled down a red colored, gelatin, yellow bean cocoction that was sweet and refreshing.
author: omar b.

description:
Perfect place for a quick snack or lunch.

I ordered the steamed rice noodles with shredded pork and fancy pork this time. It sounds odd but it is an authentic Vietnamese dish.  Rice noodle served with shredded pork, lettuce and Cha Lua ( a popular kind of Vietnamese ham ), very light on dressing, $4.50.

This place has very limited seats. I had my order to go and enjoyed it in my car. Not a heavy lunch and it hit the right spot :)
author: Helen L.

description:
you can get parking fairly easily.  not right in front but most likely right around the corner.

i had mixed feelings reading other reviews.  I did notice that people said the bbq pork was good.  so i felt that should be a thumbs up.  some places the pork is just pork and not bbq'd.

this place has sandwiches for 3.50 + tax.  So i ordered two sandwiches one bbq pork and one bbq chicken. it came out to 7.60.  Not bad.

I hear people complain about the bread.  So i asked them NOT TO TOAST IT.  

It made a HUGE difference to me.  I loved the sandwich.  In fact, i'm never gonna want them to toast it.  You should toast the bread if its not really fresh to freshen it up...in this case, the bread is fresh enough that you don't need it toasted.
author: Bing D.

description:
I felt like dropkicking myself after eating a sandwich from here. 

My first impression when I went in was "Oh man....this is gonna blow." And yet my stomach yearned me on to actually order a banh mi from here. The guy prepping the sandwiches looks like he got dropkicked in the face. He gives you this glare that radiates anger and disgust with his life. Maybe the store is his, and he's pissed off because his sandwiches suck and he hates his life. 

With all due respect, a smile goes a long way, especially when you have customers who may come back pretty often. 

The sandwich was painfully small. It was almost the size of a small Nerf football. I think I ordered the original combination pork sandwich. Plain and simple and easy to make without mistakes no? 

Well here it is. It fails. It was small, tasteless, and most of it, it cost nearly 4 bucks! 

It's sad how kids going to school around here will get jacked by this dropkick deserving place.
author: Derrick L.

description:
Not enough meat in their sandwiches(1 or 2 slices look at posted photo)and the bread is kinda hard from what I can remember 8 years ago. It's tasteless and feels as though it's being made just to be made and not made to satisfy the consumer.  Not worth the price they charge and doesn't get the job done when you're hungry.

 I'm banning Banhwitch from my list of place to go. Waste of my time and money.
author: Keit K.

description:
Vietnamese sandwich with bread ala Sub Center.
Inexpensive,
tasty,
and you won't wonder if your heart will stop ticking somewhere during digestion.
One of my favorite "on the way home from Ocean 24 hr Fitness and I'm starved" spots.
Toasty!
author: Barry A.

description:
Bahnwich has the misfortune of being my next sandwich review after the exceptional Saigon Sandwiches.

I ordered the pan-fried bbq chicken for $3.  For starters, their Sub Centeresque bread was nice and toasty.  But the filling was less interesting.  More so, the lack of filling was a problem. I found myself biting into just bread at times.  The bbq chicken didn't have much flavor and the vegetables aren't marinaded.

Still, the sandwich did temper my hunger for a bit before dinner.  Also, their rice plates are pretty decent.  About $5 a pop.
author: Sam T.

description:
I agree with the other reviewers, the sandwiches were pretty skimpy on the filling & flavor, and the service was also slow. Tried a rice dish and a spring roll (and both of us have stomach aches now...).

If you want  a so-so banh mi and stomachaches...this is the place to go.
author: Garion M.

description:
This place makes a somewhat decent sandwich. SOMEWHAT decent. Not exactly decent. Not exactly good. Somewhat decent. It has nothing to do with the guy that makes the sandwiches and just about everything else in the front but more to do with the sandwiches themselves...It's like they lack soul or something meaningful...Like, the sandwich feels lacking of something that is unattainable without the help of something...Sounds philosophical and hokey, I know, but I am passionate about food and food is passionate about me. Just ask my big belly.

There are some decent vittles in this joint. The fresh spring rolls are nice on certain days...The egg sandwich is interesting...And the hot dishes are somewhat palatable. Your miles may vary compared to mine...

All in all, a place I wouldn't frequent too often. Maybe once in a while...Maybe...
author: Anthony L.

description:
I dunno any other place on Taraval to get Vietnamese sandwich.  Used to be able to get  V sandwich from Lam's, but I think they went out of business or something.  

-1 star for candy always empty.  
-1 star for lack of other regular vietnames deli fare, like goi cuong, banh hoi, things like that.  

There used to be a younger girl who worked there, and I remember the place being very clean and well-stocked when she was there.  Place is kinda run down and the older cats there now are mean.
author: Dong T.

description: It's strange walking into a establishment when the person behind the register is young and watching the Disney Channel.  Besides that, it's cheap and delicious.  I bought two fresh spring rolls for dinner for $3.50.
author: Ashley I.

description:
Is this the new place that replaced Lam's Deli up the street?

THIS PLACE SUCKS!  There were 3 people in line and it took them 15+ minutes to get to my damn order.  And it wasn't that great.  All bread no meat.

They get the lowest possible rating for vietnamese sandwiches: 2.  I love them so much that there are some things you can't mess up as long as you're sanitary (which this place is decently clean).

Get good sandwiches--go to Saigon Sandwich
author: Steph M.

description:
Not much choice in the Sunset if you want bahn mi (viet sammies),  I just feel fortunate that I don't have to drive more than 5 minutes any more to get any...

Sammies here are good in general, but awfully inconsistent.

Avoid this place like the plague during lunch time if you don't like waiting.  With only 2 sammich-makers during peak hours, your wait can be interminable.
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Has my vote for the best Vietnamese sandwich in the city. People like Saigon Sandwiches in the TL, but I think this place rules way harder bro. 

The secret is the butter+mayonaise+who-knows-what-else spread that they use. The bread is perfectly toasted too. And the pork is sweet, not tangy like other places. Sometimes it takes a while because it's mostly just one guy working, but trust me, it's worth it.  Under $3--how it's supposed to be.
author: Steven H.

description:
I love Banhwich. They are reasonably priced and they serve good sized portions. It is a hole in the wall shop run by only two people but they manage the amount of people who come into their store well. I like the sauce that comes with their BBQ pork sandwiches. They also toast their bread too which is nice. 

The mention about the low score wasn't true when i went there today. it said 92 which is a pretty good score.
author: Josephine N.

description:
Not awesome, but not bad.  I am a huge fan of BBQ Chicken Vietnamese sandwiches, so I figured I might as well try this place since I was in the area. I am not exactly sure, but it always seems like these sandwiches take much longer than one would expect - no matter where you go.  This time it was no different - though I was a touch saddened to see my chicken had been microwaved. :(

I couldn't finish 2 sandwiches - so at least they are filling.

I will be honest w/ you though: if you are in the area, just hit up New Loi's @ 19th and Taraval - they make a mean BBQ Chicken sandwich, and the bread is a lot crisper.  But if you don't want to go to New Loi's (since it can be busy), this isn't a bad option when you are itching for banh mi.
author: Shane L.

description:
Mmm, Banhwich! I remember coming here one time (I think it was a Tuesday) and it was closed! A little piece of me died right then! Seriously, who closes that early on a TUESDAY? Whatever, I forgive them because the man behind the counter is usually friendly and makes good sandwiches! And they come pretty cheap! Mm, warm toasty Vietnamese sandwiches! Count me in! 

I would recommend taking it to go since the place is fairly small and it's usually jam-packed with teenagers during lunchtime and in the afternoon.
author: Audrey T.

description:
Need a quick bite? Low on cash? Bahnwich is the place to go. Decently sized and wonderfully delicious (sounds like Lucky Charms), you get the bang for your buck here. Quick service and simple process. You're in and out the door in five minutes. 

I especially like the chicken with cilantro WITHOUT the crazy spicy green peppers. Dab a few squirts of srirracha and you're good to go. The sandwiches are great to pack as lunches or dinner, especially since the bread doesn't get too soggy.
author: Teresa Y.

description:
I'm prefacing this by saying i havent tried the food, and i would still.  which is why it has 2 stars. if i do, i'll change the stars accordingly. the food looks cheap, only $3 for a whole sandwich..
